title: 103_hr4254
content: The "Public and Federally Assisted Housing Security Act of 1994" defines "firearm-related criminal activity" as any violation of federal or state laws regarding firearms, including the use or intended use of a firearm in a criminal act. Termination of tenancy in public housing for firearm-related criminal activity. Section 6 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to prohibit individuals or families evicted from housing due to firearm-related criminal activity from having a preference for 3 years, with the possibility of waiver under Secretary's standards. Section 6 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include waiver provisions for family members not involved in criminal activity, change references from "drug-related" to "drug- or firearm-related," and add firearm-related criminal activity to the list of prohibited actions. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OF TENANCY IN SECTION 8 HOUSING FOR FIREARM-RELATED CRIMINAL ACTIVITY. Section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to prohibit individuals or families evicted for firearm-related criminal activity from having a housing preference under the Act for 3 years. The agency can waive the application of the clause under standards set by the Secretary, including waiver for family members not involved in criminal activity. In the voucher program, individuals or families evicted for firearm-related reasons are prohibited from housing preference under the Act for 3 years. Individuals evicted from housing assisted under this Act due to firearm-related criminal activity are ineligible for a housing preference for 3 years, unless the agency waives this clause for family members not involved in the criminal activity.
